messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Here is the poem
messages.msgSnippet: I know I ve already bored you but do you know also the name of the poem? Is it JOUKISEN? If is that can you tell me with what kanji it is written? Thank you
messages.messageBody:
I know I've already bored you but do you know also the name of the poem?

Is it JOUKISEN? If is that can you tell me with what kanji it is written?

Thank you again!

Daniele

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Here is the poem
messages.msgSnippet: Are you a kind of Messiah? Thanks VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY much! I was to able to read both versions! Thank you again! Daniele
messages.messageBody:
Are you a kind of Messiah?
Thanks VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY VERY much!
I was to able to read both versions!
Thank you again!
Daniele

Oyakata <oyakata@...> wrote:
On Mon, 7 Jun 2004 10:24:16 -0700 (PDT), Daniele Frison���� wrote in message <20040607172416.5000.qmail@...>
>
>gentlemen send me a mail with, probably, japanese fonts. Am I wrong? If this
>is the true that person, Oyakata should be his nickname I think, would be so
>nice if he could send to my e-mail address that file using microsoft word or,
>better, jwpce. I apologize for this further request.

Daniel,

I've put the poem up at my website two ways. First, as regular
Japanese text, which you should be able to copy and paste into Word
or JPWCE, even if you can't read it in your internet browser.

I also put it up as a jpeg so you can see what the text will look
like when you've successfully moved it into Word/JPWCE.

Let me know if this doesn't work for you:
http://www.odanobunaga.com/jokisen.htm

--
Jay Kelly
oyakata@...

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Here is the poem
messages.msgSnippet: Unfortunately I only have the italian translation...I m attending the third year in the La Sapienza University and I m studying japanese..so I would like
messages.messageBody:
Unfortunately I only have the italian translation...I'm attending the third year in the "La Sapienza" University and I' m studying japanese..so I would like that poem in the original language to translate it. Some of you gentlemen send me a mail with, probably, japanese fonts. Am I wrong? If this is the true that person, Oyakata should be his nickname I think, would be so nice if he could send to my e-mail address that file using microsoft word or, better, jwpce. I apologize for this further request.
Thanks a lot.
Daniele

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Here is the poem
messages.msgSnippet: On Sat, 5 Jun 2004 06:42:38 -0700 (PDT), Sam Murray$B$5$s(B wrote in message  ... Would you be able to
messages.messageBody:
On Sat, 5 Jun 2004 06:42:38 -0700 (PDT), Sam Murrayさん wrote in message <20040605134238.52910.qmail@...>
>I Got it translated for you! Here it is in English:
>
>"the ocean's sleep stopped
>when the monster arrived
>after four toasts,
>in the night they didn' sleep"

Would you be able to share the original Japanese that you used to
make this translation? I shared what I believe is the original poem
earlier, but the one I have heard so often doesn't contain any
reference to monsters.

Maybe there are more than one poem out there?

Thanks!

--
Jay Kelly
oyakata@...

messages.subject: Re: [samuraihistory] Here is the poem
messages.msgSnippet: I Got it translated for you! Here it is in English: the ocean s sleep stopped when the monster arrived after four toasts, in the night they didn sleep ...
messages.messageBody:
I Got it translated for you! Here it is in English:

"the ocean's sleep stopped
when the monster arrived
after four toasts,
in the night they didn' sleep"
